action.action-desc: Mr. Coburn (for himself and Mr. Pryor) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To amend title 5, United States Code, to provide that persons having seriously delinquent tax debts shall be ineligible for Federal employment.

section.header: Ineligibility of persons having seriously delinquent tax debts for Federal employment

subsection.text: Chapter 73 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

subchapter.header: Ineligibility of persons having seriously delinquent tax debts for Federal employment

section.header: Ineligibility of persons having seriously delinquent tax debts for Federal employment

paragraph.text: the term seriously delinquent tax debt means an outstanding debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for which a notice of lien has been filed in public records pursuant to section 6323 of such Code, except that such term does not include—

subparagraph.text: a debt that is being paid in a timely manner pursuant to an agreement under section 6159 or section 7122 of such Code; and
a debt with respect to which a collection due process hearing under section 6330 of such Code, or relief under subsection (a), (b), or (f) of section 6015 of such Code, is requested or pending; and
an employee, as defined by section 2105; and
an employee of the United States Postal Service or of the Postal Regulatory Commission.

subsection.text: An individual who has a seriously delinquent tax debt shall be ineligible to be appointed, or to continue serving, as a Federal employee.

The Office of Personnel Management shall, for purposes of carrying out this section with respect to the executive branch, prescribe any regulations which the Office considers necessary, which shall include regulations authorizing each agency to establish an appeal process for affected individuals.
The analysis for chapter 73 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
